page.title:
Legislative and Regulatory Trends
Legislative and Regulatory Trends
page.enlisting:
• Incremental approach yielding to large scale reform – The prevailing wisdom: Healthcare system is broken – The new advocates for reform: Business, labor & some large insurers – MA breakthrough spurs state legislatures across the country. – 2008: The healthcare election? – Consumer-driven division / conservatives consider, liberals lament • Cost Containment – Few if any proposed solutions •
•

page.title:
Legislative and Regulatory Trends
Legislative and Regulatory Trends
page.enlisting:
• Expansion of children’s health and dental programs – SCHIP bills pass in House and Senate • House version contains guaranteed dental benefit • Senate version does not, but contains $200 million for dental grants. Also provides for premium assistance to eligible kids who join parent’s plans through work, but excludes assistance for stand-alone dental. • Need is for a “veto-proof” reconciliation, as President Bush opposes expansion on grounds that expanded kid care lays the foundation for socialized medicine. • Other issues: Medicare Advantage funding; $35 or $50 billion appropriation; anti crowd-out provisions; size of tobacco tax increases, comparative research components… •
•

page.title:
Legislative and Regulatory Trends
Legislative and Regulatory Trends
page.normal_text:
Dental Benefits Under Healthcare Reform
Dental Benefits Under
Healthcare Reform
page.enlisting:
• Regulatory micromanagement on the rise – Language assistance, provider sufficiency (timely access), rate regulation, any willing provider, assignment of benefits, prompt payment, independent review, retroactive termination, etc… • All intended to protect consumers from bad players and practices • All intended to address complaints about health plans, not dental • For low margin benefit like dental, these add up to “death by a – Emergence of the “plan enforcement model” • By regulating “practice of dentistry” through dental plans, we risk defection of dentists from panels, which equals higher costs, higher premiums and less access. (example, timely access regs) • Regulatory micromanagement on the rise
• Regulatory micromanagement on the rise
– Language assistance, provider sufficiency (timely access), rate regulation, any willing provider, assignment of benefits, prompt payment, independent review, retroactive termination, etc…

payment, independent review, retroactive termination, etc…

• Governor Mit Romney signs universal coverage in 06 – Employer and individual mandates; establishes large state agency “the connector” to coordinate private and tax-supported plans with hospitals, physician groups and insurers; establishes rules, builds marketplace where conforming products matched with purchasers. – Signaled that Democrats and Republicans can compromise on – Inspired much of CA proposed reforms and processes (more later) – Jury still out on impacts to dental; “crowd out” remains big concern; dental is option rather than mandate for commercial marketplace. Money the issue. Policymakers would like to see dental included eventually • Governor Mit Romney signs universal coverage in 06

perspective on healthcare reform
perspective on healthcare reform
1. Dental is an inseparable part of health and overall wellness 2. Dental coverage creates affordable access for millions of Americans 3. Third party dental carriers add value, quality and control 4. Everyone deserves dental coverage; not everyone has it
1. Dental is an inseparable part of health and overall wellness
2. Dental coverage creates affordable access for millions of Americans
3. Third party dental carriers add value, quality and control
4. Everyone deserves dental coverage; not everyone has it

page.normal_text:
Dental Benefits Under Healthcare Reform
Dental Benefits Under
Healthcare Reform
page.title:
Policy Implication I
Policy Implication I
page.normal_text:
Proposals that inadvertently add cost to dental benefit administration and/or new barriers to the design of lower cost alternative plan designs will reduce access to affordable dental coverage, thereby diminishing oral health.
Proposals that inadvertently add cost to dental
benefit administration and/or new barriers to the
design of lower cost alternative plan designs will
reduce access to affordable dental coverage,
thereby diminishing oral health.

Preserving the deductibility of dental benefits for employers, employees and/or adding tax credits for individuals who purchase dental benefits on a voluntary basis is critical.
Preserving the deductibility of dental benefits for employers,
employees and/or adding tax credits for individuals who
purchase dental benefits on a voluntary basis is critical.

Dental Benefits Under Healthcare Reform
Dental Benefits Under
Healthcare Reform
page.title:
Policy Implication II
Policy Implication II
page.normal_text:
• Dental carriers should be encouraged — not hindered — in efforts to develop and enforce competitive fee arrangements, equitable reimbursement and dental policies, and innovative plan designs.
• Dental carriers should be encouraged — not
hindered — in efforts to develop and enforce
competitive fee arrangements, equitable
reimbursement and dental policies, and innovative
plan designs.

to ensure necessary and appropriate care in accordance with group contracts and high professional standards.

group contracts and high professional standards.

page.title:
Final Thoughts
Final Thoughts

• Bear in mind: It’s seldom about dental. – Most dental industry challenges in the government relations arena stem from laws and/or regulations that were not proposed with dental in mind. – Our challenges continue to be shaped by larger forces: the • Bear in mind: It’s seldom about dental.
